> Actually, I think the interface marker hack is worse than
> prefixing yo=
ur methods with "tests", because it actually
> changes the type of your cla=
ss for no benefit to your
> business logic or future readers of your code. =
This kind of
> information should not appear in JavaDoc nor with javap: it
=
> should be completely hidden and available only to the tool that will
> us=
e it. 

I don't follow you here - why shouldn't it be interesting to someon=
e looking
at a testcase class to know which category it belongs to?

> Also=
, you can quickly see how using this trick to implement
> groups of tests c=
an lead to a combinatorial explosion of
> interfaces and to classes that im=
plement five or ten
> different interfaces...  Not very clean.

I don't see=
 any combinatorial explosion of interfaces - we would have one
interface pe=
r category, which sounds more like a "linear explosion" to me...
;)

I also=
 don't see a big difference between a test class implementing five or
ten i=
nterfaces or using five or ten annotations. Am I missing something?

Cheers=
, Ilja
